entity1.name: Physics of Roller Coasters
entity1.description: A type of amusement ride that uses tracks and steep inclines to create a thrilling experience for riders.;;;An amusement park ride developed for thrill and entertainment, typically consisting of a track with steep drops, sharp curves, and sometimes loops.;;;A ride in an amusement park that consists of a track with steep drops and sharp curves, designed to carry passengers at high speeds.;;;Amusement park attractions designed to provide thrilling experiences through various elements such as twists, turns, drops, and loops.;;;A vehicle designed for amusement park rides, typically moving on tracks and featuring steep drops and sharp turns.;;;The application of physical principles and laws to the design and operation of roller coasters.;;;A type of amusement ride that features a track with steep drops, sharp curves, and often loops, designed to provide thrill and excitement.;;;A large mechanical ride found in amusement parks, designed to move along a track and provide thrilling experiences.;;;Structures or vehicles designed for entertainment in amusement parks, often providing thrilling experiences to visitors.;;;An amusement park ride that consists of a track with steep drops and sharp turns, designed to provide thrill and excitement.;;;A type of amusement ride that uses elevated tracks and steep drops to create a thrilling experience for riders.;;;A type of amusement ride that consists of a track with steep drops, sharp curves, and often loops, designed to carry passengers at high speeds.;;;A type of amusement ride that uses elevated tracks to guide vehicles through various steep drops, sharp turns, and loops.;;;A vehicle used for transportation, typically with four wheels and an internal combustion engine or electric motor.;;;A type of amusement ride that features a track with steep drops, sharp turns, and sometimes loops.;;;A type of amusement ride that is typically characterized by its steep drops, sharp turns, and high speeds.;;;An amusement park ride that consists of a track with steep drops, sharp curves, and often loops, designed to provide thrill and excitement.;;;A vehicle designed for amusement park rides, typically moving on tracks with steep drops and sharp turns.;;;The natural science that involves the study of matter, its motion, and behavior through space and time, along with related concepts such as energy and force.;;;A vehicle used for transportation, in this context specifically a ride car that moves along a track.;;;A road vehicle, typically with four wheels, powered by an internal combustion engine or electric motor, used for transportation.;;;A vehicle designed for amusement park rides, typically featuring a track with steep drops and sharp turns.;;;A broad classification of entertainment facilities found in amusement parks, which include roller coasters among other attractions.;;;The scientific study of the principles and laws governing the motion, forces, and energy involved in roller coaster rides.;;;A type of amusement ride that uses elevated tracks and steep slopes to create a thrilling experience for riders.;;;A mechanical ride found in amusement parks, consisting of a track with steep drops and sharp curves designed for thrill and excitement.;;;The vehicle part of the roller coaster that carries the riders along the track.;;;The vehicle used in amusement parks for providing a thrilling ride experience to passengers.

entity5.name: Physics
entity5.description: The natural science that involves the study of matter, its motion, and behavior through space and time, along with related concepts such as energy and force.
entity5.chunkid: The Physics of Roller Coasters2;;;The Physics of Roller Coasters30

entity7.name: forces
entity7.description: Physical interactions between objects or within systems that can cause changes in motion or deformation.;;;A natural phenomenon that causes objects with mass to be attracted to each other.;;;A fundamental force of nature that causes objects with mass to attract each other.;;;A force that acts on a body moving in a circular path and is directed toward the center around which the body is moving.;;;Physical interactions between objects that cause changes in motion or deformation.;;;A natural phenomenon that causes objects to be attracted toward the center of a celestial body, such as Earth.;;;The force of attraction between two masses, such as the Earth pulling objects downward.;;;Physical interactions that cause changes in the motion or shape of objects; a key concept in physics for understanding how roller coasters operate.;;;The force that acts on a body moving in a circular path and is directed toward the center around which the body is moving.;;;The natural force of attraction exerted by a celestial body, such as Earth, causing objects to fall towards it.

entity8.name: energy conservation
entity8.description: A fundamental concept in physics that states energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed from one form to another.;;;The principle that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed from one form to another.
entity8.chunkid: The Physics of Roller Coasters3;;;The Physics of Roller Coasters28;;;The Physics of Roller Coasters17

entity9.name: acceleration
entity9.description: The rate at which the velocity of an object changes over time.;;;The rate of change of velocity, a fundamental concept in physics that describes how quickly an object's speed or direction changes.;;;The rate of change of velocity with respect to time, often described in physics as the second derivative of position with respect to time.;;;The rate of change of velocity with respect to time.;;;A measure of the rate at which an object's velocity changes with time.
entity9.chunkid: The Physics of Roller Coasters3;;;The Physics of Roller Coasters28;;;The Physics of Roller Coasters22;;;The Physics of Roller Coasters8;;;The Physics of Roller Coasters23

entity10.name: velocity
entity10.description: A measure of the rate and direction of motion, expressed as the distance traveled per unit of time in a specific direction.;;;The speed of an object in a given direction, often used to describe how fast and in what direction an object is moving.;;;A measure of the speed and direction of an object's movement, typically expressed as displacement per unit of time.;;;The rate of change of position with respect to time, including both speed and direction.
entity10.chunkid: The Physics of Roller Coasters28;;;The Physics of Roller Coasters3;;;The Physics of Roller Coasters22;;;The Physics of Roller Coasters23

entity15.name: friction
entity15.description: A force that opposes the motion of an object, often resulting from the interaction between two surfaces.;;;A force that resists the relative motion of solid surfaces, fluid layers, or material elements sliding against each other.;;;A force that resists the relative motion of objects or materials sliding against each other.
entity15.chunkid: The Physics of Roller Coasters5;;;The Physics of Roller Coasters16;;;The Physics of Roller Coasters13;;;The Physics of Roller Coasters25

entity17.name: Earth
entity17.description: The third planet from the Sun and the only known astronomical object to harbor life.

entity22.name: weightlessness
entity22.description: A condition where a person or object feels as if they are weightless, often experienced in free-fall or zero-gravity environments.

entity23.name: airtime
entity23.description: The period during which riders on a roller coaster or similar ride feel as if they are floating, due to the sensation of weightlessness.

entity24.name: riders
entity24.description: A group of people who are riding the roller coaster.;;;Individuals who participate in or experience an activity, such as riding a roller coaster.
entity24.chunkid: The Physics of Roller Coasters24;;;The Physics of Roller Coasters8

entity25.name: drop
entity25.description: A part of the roller coaster track where the train descends rapidly from a high point, creating a sensation of falling.;;;A part of a ride where the vehicle and its passengers descend rapidly, often creating a sensation of weightlessness.
entity25.chunkid: The Physics of Roller Coasters27;;;The Physics of Roller Coasters8

entity29.name: track
entity29.description: The surface or structure along which a vehicle moves, providing support and guidance.;;;The path or route that the roller coaster car follows, usually made of steel or wood.;;;The pathway or route along which a roller coaster car travels, usually made of steel or wood and designed to guide the vehicle through its course.;;;The path or route on which the car travels during the ride.
entity29.chunkid: The Physics of Roller Coasters11;;;The Physics of Roller Coasters10;;;The Physics of Roller Coasters14;;;The Physics of Roller Coasters21

entity31.name: circular path
entity31.description: A path that follows the circumference of a circle, where all points on the path are equidistant from the center.

entity41.name: Roller coaster designers
entity41.description: Individuals who design and create roller coasters for amusement parks.

entity46.name: mechanical energy
entity46.description: A form of energy that is the sum of kinetic and potential energies in a system.;;;The energy that an object possesses due to its motion, which is proportional to the mass and velocity squared of the object.;;;The total energy in a system, which is the sum of kinetic and potential energies.;;;The energy an object possesses due to its motion.
entity46.chunkid: The Physics of Roller Coasters18;;;The Physics of Roller Coasters21

entity48.name: potential energy
entity48.description: The energy an object has because of its position or configuration within a field, such as gravitational potential energy.;;;A form of stored energy that an object possesses due to its position or configuration, in this case, the height of the roller coaster car on the first hill.;;;Energy possessed by an object due to its position or configuration within a field of force.
entity48.chunkid: The Physics of Roller Coasters19;;;The Physics of Roller Coasters18;;;The Physics of Roller Coasters21

entity51.name: first hill
entity51.description: The initial and often tallest incline on a roller coaster, where the ride begins and potential energy is maximized.

entity54.name: system
entity54.description: The part of the universe being studied, which can exchange energy with its surroundings but not matter.

entity72.name: loops
entity72.description: A section of the roller coaster track that forms a complete or partial circle, causing riders to experience inverted positions and G-forces.
